Annotation: The ego we see most commonly goes by a more casual definition: an unhealthy belief in our own importance. Arrogance. Self-centered ambition.
Author: Ryan Holiday
Title: Ego Is The Enemy

Annotation: The performance artist Marina Abramović puts it directly: “If you start believing in your greatness, it is the death of your creativity.”
Author: Ryan Holiday
Title: Ego Is The Enemy

Annotation: Pursuing great work—whether it is in sports or art or business—is often terrifying. Ego soothes that fear. It’s a salve to that insecurity.
Author: Ryan Holiday
Title: Ego Is The Enemy

Annotation: Ego is stolen. Confidence is earned. Ego is self-anointed, its swagger is artifice.
Author: Ryan Holiday
Title: Ego Is The Enemy

Annotation: “abhor flatterers as you would deceivers; for both, if trusted, injure those who trust them.”

Title: Ego Is The Enemy

Annotation: Where Sherman had once been cautious, he was now confident. But unlike so many others who possess great ambition, he earned this opinion.

Title: Ego Is The Enemy

Annotation: if your belief in yourself is not dependent on actual achievement, then what is it dependent on? The answer, too often when we are just setting out, is nothing. Ego.

Title: Ego Is The Enemy

Annotation: What we see in Sherman was a man deeply tied and connected to reality. He was a man who came from nothing and accomplished great things, without ever feeling that he was in someway entitled to the honors he received.

Annotation: Blank spaces, begging to be filled in with thoughts, with photos, with stories. With what we’re going to do, with what things should or could be like, what we hope will happen. Technology, asking you, prodding you, soliciting talk.

Title: Ego Is The Enemy

Annotation: Almost universally, the kind of performance we give on social media is positive. It’s more “Let me tell you how well things are going. Look how great I am.” It’s rarely the truth: “I’m scared. I’m struggling. I don’t know.”
Author: Ryan Holiday
Title: Ego Is The Enemy

Title: Ego Is The Enemy

Annotation: So what is scarce and rare? Silence. The ability to deliberately keep yourself out of the conversation and subsist without its validation. Silence is the respite of the confident and the strong.

Title: Ego Is The Enemy

Annotation: Sherman had a good rule he tried to observe. “Never give reasons for what you think or do until you must. Maybe, after a while, a better reason will pop into your head.”

Annotation: Talk depletes us. Talking and doing fight for the same resources.

Annotation: plus, minus, and equal. Each fighter, to become great, he said, needs to have someone better that they can learn from, someone lesser who they can teach, and someone equal that they can challenge themselves against. The purpose of Shamrock’s formula is simple: to get real and continuous feedback about what they know and what they don’t know from every angle.
Author: Ryan Holiday
Title: Ego Is The Enemy

Annotation: “False ideas about yourself destroy you. For me, I always stay a student. That’s what martial arts are about, and you have to use that humility as a tool. You put yourself beneath someone you trust.” This begins by accepting that others know more than you and that you can benefit from their knowledge, and then seeking them out and knocking down the illusions you have about yourself.
Author: Ryan Holiday
Title: Ego Is The Enemy

Annotation: A true student is like a sponge. Absorbing what goes on around him, filtering it, latching on to what he can hold. A student is self-critical and self-motivated, always trying to improve his understanding so that he can move on to the next topic, the next challenge.
Author: Ryan Holiday
Title: Ego Is The Enemy

Annotation: You can’t learn if you think you already know. You will not find the answers if you’re too conceited and self-assured to ask the questions. You cannot get better if you’re convinced you are the best.
Author: Ryan Holiday
Title: Ego Is The Enemy

Annotation: We not only need to take this harsh feedback, but actively solicit it, labor to seek out the negative precisely when our friends and family and brain are telling us that we’re doing great.
Author: Ryan Holiday
Title: Ego Is The Enemy

Annotation: Opportunities are not usually deep, virgin pools that require courage and boldness to dive into, but instead are obscured, dusted over, blocked by various forms of resistance. What is really called for in these circumstances is clarity, deliberateness, and methodological determination.
Author: Ryan Holiday
Title: Ego Is The Enemy

Annotation: Passion typically masks a weakness. Its breathlessness and impetuousness and franticness are poor substitutes for discipline, for mastery, for strength and purpose and perseverance. You need to be able to spot this in others and in yourself, because while the origins of passion may be earnest and good, its effects are comical and then monstrous.
Author: Ryan Holiday
Title: Ego Is The Enemy

Annotation: What humans require in our ascent is purpose and realism. Purpose, you could say, is like passion with boundaries. Realism is detachment and perspective.

Title: Ego Is The Enemy

Find what nobody else wants to do and do it. Find inefficiencies and waste and redundancies. Identify leaks and patches to free up resources for new areas. Produce more than everyone else and give your ideas away

Title: Ego Is The Enemy

Annotation: Pride blunts the very instrument we need to own in order to succeed: our mind. Our ability to learn, to adapt, to be flexible, to build relationships, all of this is dulled by pride.

Title: Ego Is The Enemy

Annotation: Receive feedback, maintain hunger, and chart a proper course in life. Pride dulls these senses. Or in other cases, it tunes up other negative parts of ourselves: sensitivity, a persecution complex, the ability to make everything about us.

Annotation: As a young man, Bill Clinton began a collection of note cards upon which he would write names and phone numbers of friends and acquaintances who might be of service when he eventually entered politics. Each night, before he ever had a reason to, he would flip through the box, make phone calls, write letters, or add notations about their interactions. Over the years, this collection grew—to ten thousand cards (before it was eventually digitized). It’s what put him in the Oval Office and continues to return dividends.
Author: Ryan Holiday
Title: Ego Is The Enemy

Annotation: Do we love work, making a living to do work, not the other way around? Do we love practice, the way great athletes do?

Annotation: for the first couple years that you’re making stuff, what you’re making isn’t so good . . . It’s really not that great. It’s trying to be good, it has ambition to be good, but it’s not quite that good. But your taste—the thing that got you into the game—your taste is still killer, and your taste is good enough that you can tell that what you’re making is kind of a disappointment to you.

Title: Ego Is The Enemy

Annotation: Genghis Khan was not born a genius. Instead, as one biographer put it, his was “a persistent cycle of pragmatic learning, experimental adaptation, and constant revision driven by his uniquely disciplined and focused will.”
Author: Ryan Holiday
Title: Ego Is The Enemy

Annotation: The physicist John Wheeler, who helped develop the hydrogen bomb, once observed that “as our island of knowledge grows, so does the shore of our ignorance.” In other words, each victory and advancement that made Khan smarter also bumped him against new situations he’d never encountered before.

Title: Ego Is The Enemy
